content: * Studies typically find that unionized companies earn profits between 10 percent and 15 percent lower than those of comparable non-union firms. * Some unions win higher wages for their members, though many do not. But with these higher wages, unions bring less investment, fewer jobs, higher prices, and smaller 401(k) plans for everyone else. * Final union contracts typically give workers group identities instead of treating them as individuals. Unions do not have the resources to monitor each worker's performance and tailor the contract accordingly. Even if they could, they would not want to do so. Unions want employees to view the union--not their individual achievements--as the source of their economic gains. * Consequently, union contracts compress wages: They suppress the wages of more productive workers and raise the wages of the less competent. Unions redistribute wealth between workers. * A better summary of the economic research is that unions do not increase workers' wages by nearly as much as they claim and that, at a number of companies, they do not raise wages at all. * In essence, unions "tax" investments that corporations make, redistributing part of the return from these investments to their members. This makes undertaking a new investment less worthwhile. Companies respond to the union tax in the same way they respond to government taxes on investment--by investing less. * Research shows that unions directly cause firms to reduce their investments. In fact, investment drops sharply after unions organize a company. One study found that unionizing reduces capital investment by 30 percent--the same effect as a 33 percentage point increase in the corporate tax rate * The balance of economic research shows that unions do not just happen to organize firms with more layoffs and less job growth: They cause job losses. Most studies find that jobs drop at newly organized companies, with employment falling between 5 percent and 10 percent. 'http://www.heritage.org/Research/Labor/bg2775.cfm'

content: While many of the business practices and working conditions that necessitated the formation of trade unions have been rectified by law or conscience, new business practices and conditions are emerging that show a renewed need for unions in the workplace. Companies have shown a renewed view that workers are "throwaway commodities" that can be tossed aside when convenient - all in the name of corporate greed. To give you an example (and a personal one at that), the company I work for announced a few weeks ago that employees below the senior plant management level (E09 paygrade, 4 individuals at our facility at or above that paygrade) were going to be forced to take a 5% pay cut. This pay cut did not apply to those above that paygrade. These same workers were given two more bombshells - that our health insurance premiums would rise 60% (mine went from $85/mo to $135/mo) even though our HMO's (BlueCross/BlueShield) rates had only increased by 6% over last year. The second bombshell was that we would not get a cost of living increase - while at the E09 paygrade and above, it actually increased - from 6% to 9%. Since then it's been announced that in the time frame from May 2009 through September 2009 all hourly employees would be required to take 11 scheduled work days off - and we could not use our PTO/vacation time to cover the loss of pay incurred by this. These same managers are the one's whose knee-jerk reaction to the market slashed our workforce and equipment reserves down to the point that we can't even make our shipments (which have gone down significantly) on time - we went from being able to deliver 98% of our production on time down to 68% - which means increased cost because we have to ship the material by next day air rather than ship by truck - and it costs us $4,000 more per pallet to ship via air than truck. That adds up quite quickly when you consider that we currently ship over 250 pallets of material per week - of which 75 or more will require shipping by air to get there on time - that's $300,000 per week because of a lousy management decision! Another example of their bad decisions is this: Among the personnel cuts were 11 failure analysis/repair technicians (electronics technicians responsible for determining the cause of failure on items that don't pass testing and implementing corrective actions) - a move that saved about $385,000 per year - yet in a period of only 3 months the value of items awaiting analysis/repair has gone from $165,000 in February of this year to $4,200,000 as of a couple weeks ago! IMHO, a resurgence in union numbers and membership is needed in the American workplace to stop this trend. Workers are being forced to make sacrifice after sacrifice, pay cuts and benefit reductions while management and executives continue to make outlandish salaries that only increase every year. content: It amazes me sometimes how much both parties can be blind to the flaws of their "sides". Conservatives consistently fight against labor unions, mostly because they raise prices. My bonus for being the sole investigator and author of a patent? $2000. The head of human resources flies first class everywhere, but the engineer in charge of all our main programs (technical oversight of ~$2 billion of product a year) is rquired to fly coach. The debate right now is: does everyone with any brains get out of the industry or into management, or do we form a union... debate has just started, we'll see how it goes.

content: * Studies typically find that unionized companies earn profits between 10 percent and 15 percent lower than those of comparable non-union firms. * Some unions win higher wages for their members, though many do not. But with these higher wages, unions bring less investment, fewer jobs, higher prices, and smaller 401(k) plans for everyone else. * Final union contracts typically give workers group identities instead of treating them as individuals. Unions do not have the resources to monitor each worker's performance and tailor the contract accordingly. Even if they could, they would not want to do so. Unions want employees to view the union--not their individual achievements--as the source of their economic gains. * Consequently, union contracts compress wages: They suppress the wages of more productive workers and raise the wages of the less competent. Unions redistribute wealth between workers. * A better summary of the economic research is that unions do not increase workers' wages by nearly as much as they claim and that, at a number of companies, they do not raise wages at all. * In essence, unions "tax" investments that corporations make, redistributing part of the return from these investments to their members. This makes undertaking a new investment less worthwhile. Companies respond to the union tax in the same way they respond to government taxes on investment--by investing less. * Research shows that unions directly cause firms to reduce their investments. In fact, investment drops sharply after unions organize a company. One study found that unionizing reduces capital investment by 30 percent--the same effect as a 33 percentage point increase in the corporate tax rate * The balance of economic research shows that unions do not just happen to organize firms with more layoffs and less job growth: They cause job losses. Most studies find that jobs drop at newly organized companies, with employment falling between 5 percent and 10 percent. 'http://www.heritage.org/Research/Labor/bg2775.cfm'

content: While many of the business practices and working conditions that necessitated the formation of trade unions have been rectified by law or conscience, new business practices and conditions are emerging that show a renewed need for unions in the workplace. Companies have shown a renewed view that workers are "throwaway commodities" that can be tossed aside when convenient - all in the name of corporate greed. To give you an example (and a personal one at that), the company I work for announced a few weeks ago that employees below the senior plant management level (E09 paygrade, 4 individuals at our facility at or above that paygrade) were going to be forced to take a 5% pay cut. This pay cut did not apply to those above that paygrade. These same workers were given two more bombshells - that our health insurance premiums would rise 60% (mine went from $85/mo to $135/mo) even though our HMO's (BlueCross/BlueShield) rates had only increased by 6% over last year. The second bombshell was that we would not get a cost of living increase - while at the E09 paygrade and above, it actually increased - from 6% to 9%. Since then it's been announced that in the time frame from May 2009 through September 2009 all hourly employees would be required to take 11 scheduled work days off - and we could not use our PTO/vacation time to cover the loss of pay incurred by this. These same managers are the one's whose knee-jerk reaction to the market slashed our workforce and equipment reserves down to the point that we can't even make our shipments (which have gone down significantly) on time - we went from being able to deliver 98% of our production on time down to 68% - which means increased cost because we have to ship the material by next day air rather than ship by truck - and it costs us $4,000 more per pallet to ship via air than truck. That adds up quite quickly when you consider that we currently ship over 250 pallets of material per week - of which 75 or more will require shipping by air to get there on time - that's $300,000 per week because of a lousy management decision! Another example of their bad decisions is this: Among the personnel cuts were 11 failure analysis/repair technicians (electronics technicians responsible for determining the cause of failure on items that don't pass testing and implementing corrective actions) - a move that saved about $385,000 per year - yet in a period of only 3 months the value of items awaiting analysis/repair has gone from $165,000 in February of this year to $4,200,000 as of a couple weeks ago! IMHO, a resurgence in union numbers and membership is needed in the American workplace to stop this trend. Workers are being forced to make sacrifice after sacrifice, pay cuts and benefit reductions while management and executives continue to make outlandish salaries that only increase every year. content: It amazes me sometimes how much both parties can be blind to the flaws of their "sides". Conservatives consistently fight against labor unions, mostly because they raise prices. This is largely true. But we have consistently seen how corporations (as a group, there are exceptions) see worker compensation and benefits as a method for reducing costs without touching the "decision makers" compensation. If you want to see "how to do it" see Wegman's - they cannot be unionized. Then see how many corporations can meet that standard. Liberals consistently fight for labor unions, because they protect the workers. Unfortunately, many unions (in the name of protecting the worker) create competitively crippling wage scales while at the same time protecting inferior workers at the expense of the superior. As with many systems, the unions are progressively serving their leadership over the constituency. You know - like corporate management, or Congress. Personal note - I am an engineer for a defense contractor. I made a $3000 bonus for writing a small section of a winning proposal last year. My bonus for being the sole investigator and author of a patent? $2000. The head of human resources flies first class everywhere, but the engineer in charge of all our main programs (technical oversight of ~$2 billion of product a year) is rquired to fly coach. The debate right now is: does everyone with any brains get out of the industry or into management, or do we form a union... debate has just started, we'll see how it goes.

content: * Studies typically find that unionized companies earn profits between 10 percent and 15 percent lower than those of comparable non-union firms. * Some unions win higher wages for their members, though many do not. But with these higher wages, unions bring less investment, fewer jobs, higher prices, and smaller 401(k) plans for everyone else. * Final union contracts typically give workers group identities instead of treating them as individuals. Unions do not have the resources to monitor each worker's performance and tailor the contract accordingly. Even if they could, they would not want to do so. Unions want employees to view the union--not their individual achievements--as the source of their economic gains. * Consequently, union contracts compress wages: They suppress the wages of more productive workers and raise the wages of the less competent. Unions redistribute wealth between workers. * A better summary of the economic research is that unions do not increase workers' wages by nearly as much as they claim and that, at a number of companies, they do not raise wages at all. * In essence, unions "tax" investments that corporations make, redistributing part of the return from these investments to their members. This makes undertaking a new investment less worthwhile. Companies respond to the union tax in the same way they respond to government taxes on investment--by investing less. * Research shows that unions directly cause firms to reduce their investments. In fact, investment drops sharply after unions organize a company. One study found that unionizing reduces capital investment by 30 percent--the same effect as a 33 percentage point increase in the corporate tax rate * The balance of economic research shows that unions do not just happen to organize firms with more layoffs and less job growth: They cause job losses. content: While many of the business practices and working conditions that necessitated the formation of trade unions have been rectified by law or conscience, new business practices and conditions are emerging that show a renewed need for unions in the workplace. Companies have shown a renewed view that workers are "throwaway commodities" that can be tossed aside when convenient - all in the name of corporate greed. To give you an example (and a personal one at that), the company I work for announced a few weeks ago that employees below the senior plant management level (E09 paygrade, 4 individuals at our facility at or above that paygrade) were going to be forced to take a 5% pay cut. This pay cut did not apply to those above that paygrade. These same workers were given two more bombshells - that our health insurance premiums would rise 60% (mine went from $85/mo to $135/mo) even though our HMO's (BlueCross/BlueShield) rates had only increased by 6% over last year. The second bombshell was that we would not get a cost of living increase - while at the E09 paygrade and above, it actually increased - from 6% to 9%. Since then it's been announced that in the time frame from May 2009 through September 2009 all hourly employees would be required to take 11 scheduled work days off - and we could not use our PTO/vacation time to cover the loss of pay incurred by this. These same managers are the one's whose knee-jerk reaction to the market slashed our workforce and equipment reserves down to the point that we can't even make our shipments (which have gone down significantly) on time - we went from being able to deliver 98% of our production on time down to 68% - which means increased cost because we have to ship the material by next day air rather than ship by truck - and it costs us $4,000 more per pallet to ship via air than truck. That adds up quite quickly when you consider that we currently ship over 250 pallets of material per week - of which 75 or more will require shipping by air to get there on time - that's $300,000 per week because of a lousy management decision! Another example of their bad decisions is this: Among the personnel cuts were 11 failure analysis/repair technicians (electronics technicians responsible for determining the cause of failure on items that don't pass testing and implementing corrective actions) - a move that saved about $385,000 per year - yet in a period of only 3 months the value of items awaiting analysis/repair has gone from $165,000 in February of this year to $4,200,000 as of a couple weeks ago! IMHO, a resurgence in union numbers and membership is needed in the American workplace to stop this trend. Workers are being forced to make sacrifice after sacrifice, pay cuts and benefit reductions while management and executives continue to make outlandish salaries that only increase every year. content: It amazes me sometimes how much both parties can be blind to the flaws of their "sides". Conservatives consistently fight against labor unions, mostly because they raise prices. This is largely true. But we have consistently seen how corporations (as a group, there are exceptions) see worker compensation and benefits as a method for reducing costs without touching the "decision makers" compensation. If you want to see "how to do it" see Wegman's - they cannot be unionized. Then see how many corporations can meet that standard. Liberals consistently fight for labor unions, because they protect the workers. Unfortunately, many unions (in the name of protecting the worker) create competitively crippling wage scales while at the same time protecting inferior workers at the expense of the superior. As with many systems, the unions are progressively serving their leadership over the constituency. You know - like corporate management, or Congress. Personal note - I am an engineer for a defense contractor. I made a $3000 bonus for writing a small section of a winning proposal last year. My bonus for being the sole investigator and author of a patent? $2000. The head of human resources flies first class everywhere, but the engineer in charge of all our main programs (technical oversight of ~$2 billion of product a year) is rquired to fly coach. The debate right now is: does everyone with any brains get out of the industry or into management, or do we form a union... debate has just started, we'll see how it goes.
